column1: Wooster ( WUUS-tər) is a city in the U.S. state of Ohio and the county seat of Wayne County. The municipality is located in northeastern Ohio approximately 50 mi (80 km) SSW of Cleveland
column2: 35 mi (56 km) SW of Akron and 30 mi (48 km) W of Canton. The population was 24
column4: 119 at the 2010 Census. The city is the largest in Wayne County
column5: and the center of the Wooster Micropolitan Statistical Area (as defined by the United States Census Bureau). Wooster has the main branch and administrative offices of the Wayne County Public Library.The College of Wooster is located in Wooster.

column1: fDi magazine ranked Wooster among North America's top 10 micro cities for business friendliness and strategy in 2013.
Wooster was established in 1808 by John Bever
column3: and Joseph Larwill and named after David Wooster
column4: a general in the American Revolutionary War.

column1: Wooster is the headquarters of several industrial entities.  Buehler Food Markets Inc.
column6: and Certified Angus Beef have corporate headquarters located in Wooster.  Rubbermaid made its corporate headquarters in Wooster until the end of 2003. LuK
column7: the German maker of dual-clutch transmissions has its North America headquarters in Wooster where mainly torque converters are produced. Other large commercial operations in Wooster are Frito-Lay

column1: Wooster is also the world headquarters of the Prentke Romich Company (PRC) which  is a member of a consortium of companies that produce assistive technology and augmentative communication devices.For its size
column2: Wooster is also dedicated to the "industry of education."  It has The College of Wooster
column3: and two subsidiaries of The Ohio State University:  the Agricultural Technical Institute (ATI); and the Ohio Agricultural Research and Development Center (OARDC)
column4: a teaching and research facility dedicated to agricultural science.

column2: Wooster remains an agricultural center for Ohio.  The OARDC enriches the local farms with knowledge and expertise
column3: which is proudly displayed at the annual Wayne County Fair
column4: held each September (see also Fair).  Students in Wooster and surrounding rural communities continue to enroll in youth farming programs such as 4-H and National FFA Organization.  Many Amish farmers come to Wooster by horse-and-buggy for commerce as well.

column1: The overlap of strong education and advanced manufacturing has led to number of small innovative firms being founded in Wooster in recent years including Quasar Energy Group

column6: a collective year round farmer's market for locally produced goods. At present
column7: there are over 150 local farmers and producers. Local Roots has garnered national attention for its innovative efforts.The Wayne County Airport (BJJ) serves as an air access point for many of the businesses throughout the city.

column1: Wooster was the home to the Wooster Korn Kings
column2: which was a minor league professional ice hockey team that was a member of the All American Hockey League.  The team's home arena was Alice Noble Ice Arena.

column1: The Wooster Oilers began playing at the Alice Noble Ice Arena in 2006. The team competes in the North American 3 Hockey League
column2: and won the 2009–2010 championship. The team moves players to higher levels of junior or college hockey.

column1: The city is governed by an elected mayor. On January 1
column3: former Councilman Bob Breneman (R) was sworn in as Mayor.There is a seven-member City Council: Mark Cavin (D-1st Ward)
column8: Jon Ansel (R) and Craig Sanders (R). Meetings are presided over by Mike Buytendyk (R) the City Council president who is elected at-large and only votes to break a tie. Jon Ansel is the council president pro tempore.
